text: "What’s wrong with you today?" I stared into her eyes. "From the moment you walked in, it’s like you froze yourself solid."
Her gaze lifted—like a blade slipping free of its sheath for just a moment.
"You don’t need to know."
The words were brief, but they shut the door completely. Lucia froze mid-motion, the salve hovering in her hand, clearly flustered.
"Master… he’s just worried about you."
"Worried?" she repeated softly, as if tasting a word that didn’t belong here.
"Lucia, don’t teach others to interfere."
Lucia’s eyes reddened at once. She held back her tears and instead pulled the medicine basket closer to the counter, as if tightening her grip could somehow pull the situation back under control.
"You could at least—"
"No."
"Today, I just want to rest."
She stood up. Her cloak swayed lightly, as if carrying all her emotions away with it.
"Two rooms."
"Give her the key."
"I—I understand…"
She headed upstairs, her footsteps frighteningly light, as if she were afraid that making even the slightest sound might cause her to crack.
The creak of the stairs faded, leaving only the crackle of the fireplace in the inn.
Lucia bit her lip and forced out a small smile as she said, "I’m sorry"—apologizing on her master’s behalf.
I let out a breath and shook my head. "It’s fine."
Lucia seemed to relax just a little, though her shoulders were still tense, her fingers gripping the edge of the basket until they turned white.
"If she needs rest, then let her rest," I said, glancing toward the stairs. "And don’t push yourself too hard either."
She sniffed and nodded hard. "…Okay. I’ll keep an eye on her."
A log popped softly in the fireplace. The inn sank back into that heavy quiet, as if all unspoken words had been forced to swallow themselves.
